content.text: Here's a message with some **markdown** formatting, `inline code`, and even a [link](https://example.com). Let's see how it renders!

Great example! Markdown formatting is indeed supported. Here are some more examples:

## Headers work too

### Sublevel headers

- Bullet points
- **Bold text**
- *Italic text*
- `inline code`

> Block quotes look nice

```python
# Code blocks with syntax highlighting
def hello_world():
    print("Hello, world!")
    return 42
```

| Tables | Also | Work |
|--------|------|------|
| Cell 1 | Cell 2 | Cell 3 |
| Data   | More  | Info  |

The markdown renderer handles all of this automatically!

Let's test a very long message to see how it handles text wrapping and layout. input.test_param: This tool will fail to demonstrate error handling

toolUseResult: Error: Tool execution failed with error: Command not found

content.content: Error: Tool execution failed with error: Command not found

content.text: Caveat: The messages below were generated by the user while running local commands. DO NOT respond to these messages or otherwise consider them in your response unless the user explicitly asks you to.

<command-name>test-command</command-name><command-args>--verbose --output /tmp/test.log</command-args><command-message>Running a test command to verify system functionality</command-message><command-contents>{"text": "This is the actual command content with some JSON structure and escaped characters: \"quotes\" and \nline breaks\n"}</command-contents>

<local-command-stdout>Command output here:
Line 1 of output
Line 2 of output
Some data: 12345
Status: SUCCESS
Timestamp: 2025-06-14T11:02:20Z</local-command-stdout>
I see the long Lorem ipsum text wraps nicely! Long text handling is important for readability. The CSS should handle word wrapping automatically.
Testing special characters: caf√©, na√Øve, r√©sum√©, ‰∏≠Êñá, ÿßŸÑÿπÿ±ÿ®Ÿäÿ©, —Ä—É—Å—Å–∫–∏–π, üéâ emojis üöÄ and symbols ‚àë‚àÜ‚àöœÄ‚àû

summary: Tested various edge cases including markdown formatting, long text, tool errors, system messages, command outputs, special characters and emojis. All message types render correctly in the transcript viewer.
